Award.AwardTitle: ATD: An Integrated Framework of Network Theory, Data Mining and Partial Differential Equation for Early Detection of Epidemic Outbreaks
Award.AbstractNarration:
Despite advancements in medical technology and vaccines, emerging and reemerging epidemics such as SARS, influenza A (H1N1), avian influenza, Ebola, and Zika continue to pose tremendous threats. Early detection and immediate response are essential to avoid societal repercussions. However, in many cases, current methods and algorithms for epidemic detection cannot account for the wealth of social media data available today. This data provides an opportunity to develop improved surveillance systems. This project will develop a novel integrated framework for early detection of epidemic outbreaks based on real-time geo-tagged Twitter data. The work combines the expertise of scientists in both mathematics and computer science and will develop new algorithms for faster detection (near real-time and localized) of epidemic outbreaks. Effective early detection of epidemics in localized regions will greatly increase governmental agency and health organization awareness, prompting appropriate actions to control and treat epidemics. This project will significantly enhance public health awareness and preparedness against epidemic outbreaks.

The project will develop new methodologies and algorithms for early and accurate detection of epidemic outbreaks with social media data. To this end, the project will introduce new algorithms in community detection/clustering and hot topic analysis of geo-tagged Twitter data. The work will also define effective distance metrics that combine the structure of underlying social networks, physical proximity, and travel information to capture the pattern of epidemic spread. As a result, solutions of partial differential equation models, which describe spatio-temporal patterns of epidemic spread, are used to provide an early warning indicator for predicting imminence of an outbreak. In addition, new algorithms and theorems from partial differential equations will reveal epidemic spread mechanisms. The project will produce a new trans-disciplinary framework of network theory, data mining, and partial differential equations for epidemic detection with geo-tagged Twitter data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Infectious diseases such as influenza and COVID-19 have posed tremendous threats to our societies. Early detection and immediate response are essential to avoid the repercussions of an epidemic.  We established an integrated framework at the interface of partial differential equations (PDE), network theory and data mining with geo-tagged data from social networks such as Twitter and Google. This project demonstrated the feasibility of the PDE modeling framework for real-time detection of epidemic outbreaks. 

We have proposed several PDE models to describe and predict the spread of influenza in the U.S. and COVID-19 in Arizona, and developed new algorithms in community detection/clustering and hot topic analysis of geo-tagged data. Based on the new clustering algorithms, we introduced new effective distance metrics reflecting the structure of underlying social networks and physical proximity to capture the spreading pattern of influenza and COVID-19. New mathematical theorems of partial differential equations are developed to reveal mechanisms of the spread of epidemics and enrich our understanding of partial differential equations and their applications in social networks. The extension of partial differential equations into social networks presents new opportunities and challenges for mathematicians as well as computer scientists and researchers in social media.

The project results in 10 publications including 9 journal articles and one book with Springer.  Our published results in flu prediction demonstrate that the partial differential equation model on social networks can accurately predict the prevalence of influenza in the U.S. The integration of the clustering, embedding algorithms and partial differential equation models significantly improves influenza prediction as social activities and hidden communities/clusters are incorporated into the model. 

Arizona emerges as one of the country’s newest COVID-19 hot spots in June 2020.  We applied the PDE modeling framework to the spread of COVID-19 in Arizona. Our published results provide a forecasting model for COVID-19 cases with human activity data from Google. Our results demonstrate that, for the first time, a partial differential equation model can accurately predict the spread of COVID-19 cases. Base on this model, we demonstrate the effectiveness of social distancing and face covering on combating COVID-19 in Arizona. 

Furthermore, we built a website for real-time flu surveillance that provides prediction of flu case status from flu signals embedded in Twitter. New clustering algorithms and new results from topic analysis for Geo-tagged data in Twitter are incorporated to provide faster, near real-time, and localized detection of flu outbreaks. 

Finally, as a result of the project, we develop new courses at the interface of math and computer science for our undergraduate students at ASU.  We provided research opportunities for 10 undergraduate students in Applied Math and Applied Computing Programs at ASU West, including minority students and student with disability. One student poster won the first place award at ASU New College Undergraduate Student Research Expo in Spring 2018 and one won Honorable Mention award at ASU New College Undergraduate Student Research Expo in Spring 2019. The students gained math research, programming, and reporting skills in this project. They also had the opportunity to work with people from different disciplines since this project involves researchers from computer science and math. Some of the undergraduate students are coauthors of our publications.
